Description: A thin needle with an eye: made by cutting from thin sheet copper and hammering to a more rounded shape. The section is roughly circular near the tip but becomes square higher up.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II, 28, pl.IXA, 5. For other examples of Early Dynastic needles, see W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II, pls.XXXV, 84-9; XXXVIII, 76, 93; XLI, 86; XLIII, 13-4; XLIV, 49; XLV, 18, 70;W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tombs of the courtiers and Oxyrhynkos' (London, 1925), pls.IV, V, 1, 4, 12, 18; W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' I' (Cairo, 1949), 50 and pl.9B; E. Amélineau, ‘Les Nouvelles Fouilles d’Abydos’ II (1896-7), pl.XVIII, 2; J. E. Quibell, ‘Archaic Objects’ (Cairo, 1905), nos. 14574, 14585;W. C. Hayes, 'The scepter of Egypt : a background for the study of the Egyptian antiquities in the Metropolitan Museum of Art' I (Cambridge, Mass, 1953), 46, fig. 36; Z. Y. Saad, 'The excavations at Helwan art and civilization in the first and second Egyptian dynasties' (Norman, 1969), pl.37; ; A. Scharff, ‘Die Altertümer der Vor – und Frühzeit Ägyptens’ I (Berlin, 1929), nos. 129-30 and pl. 7.
